poem.content:
The kingdom sleeps, a walnut shell so deep,
Where cabbage dreams stain gardens green and low.
An alien light, a violet, cold steep,
Casts down a moral glare, a spectral glow.

Buffalo roam, in fields of phantom rye,
Their heavy steps, a rhythm in the haze.
The parrot squawks, a question to the sky:
Will cinnamonâ€™s promise light these days?

Remain, it whispers, to the earth so brown,
Remain, as seasons turn, and shadows creep.
Biology unfolds, then shuts back down,
Like secrets buried, promises to keep.

The future beckons, always just ahead,
A winding path through mists we cannot see.
This soapy world, lies softly on its bed,
So soon forgotten, just a memory.

The glare softens, soon the violet fades,
The alien gone, as needed, as it came,
Leaving only cinnamon scented cascades,
And whispers of a yet unknown fame.
